nodes.name: Decision making process
nodes.text:
Decision making process

Decision making in the operations phase of a green bank covers how the decisions are made to ensure that the institution remains aligned with its mission and mandate, as well as sticking to its green standards. In the operations phase decision-making may cover decisions taken both inside and outside the bank, and may require greater effort its to ensure the decisions taken at senior levels are fully reflected in the day-to-day procedures of the bank. Many of these choices are made at board level and set the course for the institution:

Key questions:

  • How does the board interact with its shareholders?
  • How does the nonexecutive board ensure that the bank keeps to its mission?
  • How does the board set the strategy? Who approves it?
  • How does the board manage risk?
  • What operations need to be outsourced? What are the implications?

nodes.name: Stakeholder engagement
nodes.text:
Stakeholder engagment

The stakeholder engagement in this phase is focussed on the stakeholders who will interact with and shape the bank as it goes about its day-to-day business. This will include both managing its relationship with government and any other shareholders, as well as with financiers and industry as it builds up its operations and project pipeline.

Key questions:

  • To whom is the institution accountable?
  • How does the bank interact with government?
  • How can the institution shift the perception of green investments?
  • How does the bank interact with the financial sector and project developers?

nodes.name: Analytical support
nodes.text:
Analytical support

In this phase, the analytical support focusses on giving those responsible for the bank’s performance the tools and support necessary to ensure that the Green Bank is in line with best in class practice. This will include supporting those within the bank to allow the bank to optimise both its green impact and its financial performance, whilst also providing those tasked with overseeing the bank the tools to accurately assess its performance.

Key questions:

  • How is the bank ensuring green impact and sustainability criteria are met?
  • How is the bank ensuring financial performance?
  • How should the GIB attract the best expertise from the finance sector?
  • How does the institution demonstrate additionality (if required)?
  • How is the institution developing the pipeline and providing advice to developers?

nodes.name: Standards and frameworks
nodes.text:
Standards and frameworks

Frameworks enable a green bank to consistently report and manage their operations, meeting their legal, risk and financial requirements. There are detailed further in addressing the following questions:

Key questions:

  • What is the monitoring of green performance criteria and how are these reported?
  • What is the governance framework for the institution?
  • What is the risk appetite of the institution, and is this legally binding?
  • Which instruments provide the necessary leverage?
  • Is there a requirement to demonstrate additionality?

nodes.name: Operations
nodes.text: The operations phase focuses on how the bank goes about its work in its initial years. Whilst the headline targets and overall direction for the bank will have been set in earlier phases, how these are interpreted and put into practice will have a significant impact on the efficacy of the bank.
